Award.AwardTitle: Tool Temperature Measurement during Diamond Turning of Steel

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to measure the temperature at the tool/workpiece interface during precision machining for depths of cut less than 10 micrometers to an accuracy of 5 degrees Celsius. To make this measurement, a number of important sensors will be added to a precision lathe that already has 3-dimensional force sensors. Visual and infrared microscope systems will be added to view the material flow in the chip at small depths of cut. These will provide an overall view of the temperature distribution in relation to the chip/tool interface. In addition, a unique elliptically shaped, light-guiding diamond tool will be fabricated to focus the infrared radiation from the tool tip into a spectrometer and improve the sensitivity of the peak tool temperature measurement. A unique wear measurement technique will be used to compare the tool wear with changes in material, depth of cut, temperature and cutting distance.

Keeping the tool edge sharp and avoiding degradation with time are key factors in machining materials like steel where chemical wear due to temperature dominates. Models of the machining process are available to calculate tool temperature, but measurements are needed to corroborate these results. If successful, the benefits and impact of this research will be improved knowledge of precision manufacturing processes and education of scientists and engineers. The proposed temperature measurement is needed to 1) corroborate models of the machining process and 2) predict tool wear when machining important structural materials like steel. Optical and precision mechanical systems play a pervasive role in modern life in the US and require nanometer-scale fabrication processes to yield the required performance. There is a critical need to improve these manufacturing processes, to visualize new processes and to educate the next generation of students needed to create them. The technical results will be published in engineering journals and integrated into university courses. The graduate and undergraduate students involved will develop expertise in key areas like machine design, control, materials response, dynamic systems and precision manufacturing.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to measure the temperature at the interface between a diamond tool and a steel workpiece. The temperature was to be related to the volume of wear on the tool for a variety of operating conditions and workpiece materials. A model of the tool wear was the goal. Unfortunately the issue of built-up-edge came to the forefront and required a change in scope of the project to look at both tool wear and BUE.

Intellectual Merit

Surface Finish The goal of machining with a diamond tool is to utilize its high-quality geometry and edge sharpness to create a surface with low roughness and minimum form error.  As applied to non-ferrous metals and plastics, DT can produce mirror finishes and form error less than 100 nm.  However, extrapolating this performance to steel work-pieces has proven difficult.

  • Built Up Edge (BUE) BUE occurs when the workpiece material sticks to the rake and flank rake of the tool. This occurs in ferrous materials that work harden materials, such as steel, but it also happens when machining aluminum alloys that also work harden. This process is considered to occur dynamically and potentially at a cyclical rate. BUE affects surface finish by effectively changing the geometry of the cutting edge and thus, the cutting process. Experiments were done to examine the effect of BUE on the workpiece as well as to measure the shape of the BUE using an SEM. 
  • Tool Wear While machining ferrous material, diamond tool wear occurs at a much higher rate than when machining non-ferrous materials. This affects the cutting process by changing the cutting edge of the tool. Once the tool is measured with the BUE in place, the build-up is chemically removed and any changes to the diamond edge are measured. The volumetric wear can be quantified by averaging multiple measurements along the length of the cutting edge. The results indicates that the BUE is cyclic and the tool wear alternates with pickup. Different cutting conditions were investigated to observe the effect on the tool wear with an emphasis on temperature and tool wear.

 

Tool Temperature Previous work on diamond tool wear while machining steel blamed higher tool temperatures for the increased chemical wear. The initial goal was to measure the peak temperature and use this in a model to estimate the chemical wear. 

  • Measurement The peak temperature in a machining process typically occurs along the primary shear zone in the chip and along the edge of the tool.  The diamond tool is an excellent thermal conductor and will efficiently transfer the heat generated at the shearing interface to the bulk of the tool. Diamond tool temperatures were made using thin film platinum Resistance Temperature Detectors (RTDs) mounted to the tool. This sensor was used to extrapolate to the peak temperature at the tool/workpiece interface using a FEM thermal model of the tool. The peak temperatures are on the order of 200C for typical diamond turning conditions.
  • Finite Element Modeling AdvantEdge is a Finite Element model for a machining process that can provide insight into the details of the forces and temperature at the tool edge. Operating conditions used for the experiments were modeled and the results compared to understand the effect of machining parameters on forces, heat generation, chip formation, tool temperature and tool wear. An analysis of the heat partitioning between the workpiece, chip and tool was developed to examine the effects machining parameters.

Broader Impact

The objective of this project was to elucidate the circumstances that make it difficult to machine ferrous metals (steel and stainless steel) with a diamond tool and replicate the excellent surface finish typically achieved with a variety of non-ferrous metals. This is important because hard ferrous metals are extensively used to make injection-molding dies but significant post machine polishing is required to produce acceptable mold surface finish. Contributing factors such as tool wear, pick up on the tool edge (BUE), tool temperature and forces during the machining process were investigated. The results along with finite element models and previous research in the ultra-precision machining resulted in improved understanding and potentially a way to improve the surface finish.


Last Modified: 09/27/2016
Modified by: Thomas A Dow
